author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Open source is reshaping everything from internet trust to network AI, insurance data to media pipelines.

🧠 What happens when the Linux kernel takes CVEs into its own hands?
📡 How do you build cloud-native networks with AI at the core?
🎥 Can broadcast media finally go cloud-native?
📈 Why is geospatial innovation being held back by one specific data problem?
🛡️ What does internet trust look like behind the scenes?

Watch this week’s LF Quick Hits! 

#OpenSource #Cybersecurity #Networking #Cloud #Geospatial
title: From Kernel CVEs to Cloud AI: This Week in Open Source Innovation

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Join Sven Tiffe, Engineering Manager for Bazel and Joe Hicks, Product Manager for Bazel, as he shares community updates, key initiatives, and more. 

Resources:
Contributions → https://goo.gle/3oebwcj

Speakers:
Sven Tiffe, Joe Hicks


#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Sven Tiffe, Joe Hicks; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Bazel community updates

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Want to learn how design custom silicon with the same workflow you use to build software with Bazel? Come to this talk for an overview of how the https://github.com/hdl/bazel_rules_hdl repo allows you to do just that.

Resources:
Open MPW Shuttle Program FAQs → https://goo.gle/3bVnGRI
Request invite to the skywater-pdk Slack! → https://goo.gle/3klTmEf
Projects that need your help:
The-OpenROAD-Project → https://goo.gle/3wzSHnB
YosysHQ → https://goo.gle/3BYRiIr
KLayout → https://goo.gle/303Uu8R
hdl/bazel_rules_hdl → https://goo.gle/2YtAE63
Google/xls → https://goo.gle/3EYxLJX


Speaker:
Ethan Moon Mahintorabi

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Ethan Moon Mahintorabi; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Build custom silicon with Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Jeff Cox, Engineering Director of Google’s software Build, Test, and Release functions, will open up BazelCon 2021 with the “State of Bazel”, announcements, high level Bazel roadmap, and more. This keynote discussion about Bazel’s strategic direction is one that can’t be missed.

Speaker:
Jeff Cox

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Jeff Cox; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Keynote - State of Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
The Starlark debugger remains an under-appreciated and underused tool in the Bazel ecosystem. Join us on a deep dive of the debug architecture, how to run it, what works, and what is not supported. The presentation will be largely demo-based in the context of the debug adapter protocol and VSCode.

Resources:
Bazel support for Visual Studio Code → https://goo.gle/3BXdylO
A standalone debugger for Starlark → https://goo.gle/3kj0SzO

Speaker:
Paul Cody Johnston



#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Paul Cody Johnston; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Starlark Debugger: Deep dive

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
The complexities of identifying and tracking open-source software (OSS) to comply with license requirements adds friction to the development process and can result in product-release delays. At VMware, we solve this problem using Bazel to create an accurate bill of materials containing OSS and third-party packages during a build.

Resources:
OSS audit → https://goo.gle/30g55xc

Speaker:
Daniel Machlab

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Daniel Machlab; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Streamlining VMware's open source license compliance using Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
At present, the language specific rules (Java, C++, Android) are part of Bazel's binary and their unit tests are not exposed, which makes the changes to the rules in Bazel difficult, especially for the open source community. The Bazel team will reimplement those rules and their tests in Starlark and move them to their own repositories and because of this the contributions to the rules will become easier. 

Speaker:
Ivo List

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Ivo List; re_ty: Publish;"
title: The future of language-specific rules in Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Development environments are moving to the cloud and Bazel is perfectly positioned to ride this wave. Learn how to configure Github Codespaces to take full advantage of Bazel's remote build execution capabilities for blazing fast builds in the cloud.

Resources:
User-friendly launcher for Bazel → https://goo.gle/3qkESZe
Gitpod → https://goo.gle/31KhCcP
Coder: The Developer Workspace Platform → https://goo.gle/3EYAZxa
Firecracker VM → https://goo.gle/3BUlyE9

Speaker:
Siggi Simonarson

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Siggi Simonarson; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Bazel in the Cloud: GitHub Codespaces and remote execution

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Lessons learned from migrating millions LOC, decade-old iOS App to Bazel.

Speaker:
Xiaoyi Shi

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Xiaoyi Shi; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Bazelize a gigantic iOS app

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Introducing bzlmod, Bazel's new external dependency management system.

Resources:
Central registry of Bazel modules for the Bzlmod external dependency system → https://goo.gle/304piGw
BCR Presubmit → https://goo.gle/3F4iqYt

Speakers:
Xudong Yang, Yun Peng

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Xudong Yang, Yun Peng; re_ty: Publish;"
title: bzlmod: Bazel's new external dependency system

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Learn about bazel-multiversion, a CLI tool Build team at Twitter developed to provide multiversion support for 3rdparty/jvm libraries (like Kafka and Guava). I am also discussing the motivation behind multiversioning as well as workarounds we used to overcome its limitations.

Resources:
Twitter/bazel-multiversioning → https://goo.gle/3EWExzR

Speaker:
Eugene Yokota

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Eugene Yokota; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Resolving Twitter's 3rdparty/jvm with bazel-multiversion

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Airin is a framework for automated migration to Bazel. It’s two primary components are (1) Starlark Template Engine, a declarative, typesafe Starlark template engine and code generator, and (2) Migration component, a plugin to the build system of your project that automates migration processes and generates corresponding Bazel scripts. Initially targets Gradle but not restricted with it.

Resources:
Morfly/airin → https://goo.gle/3bR9oBp
Automated migration of your projects to Bazel build system with Airin → https://goo.gle/3wtcO6L

Speaker:
Pavlo Stavytskyi

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Pavlo Stavytskyi; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Automated migration from Gradle to Bazel with Airin

author: The Linux Foundation
description: The complexities of identifying and tracking open-source software (OSS) to comply with license requirements adds friction to the development process and can result in product-release delays. At VMware, we solve this problem using Bazel to create an accurate bill of materials containing OSS and third-party packages during a build.
title: BazelCon: Streamlining VMware

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Join us as we review the concept of implicit bias, and learn tactics for mitigating it both personally and professionally in the broader context of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging. 

Speaker:
Lauren Thomas Ewing
 

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Lauren Thomas Ewing; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Implicit bias mitigation: Making the unconscious conscious

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Join us as we share a linear regression algorithm with feature crossing that predicts the CPU-time of a Bazel build. This model will allow developers to design code for efficient use of resources in advance of executing the build. 

Speakers:
Muhammad Umar Nadeem, Sarah Raza

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Muhammad Umar Nadeem, Sarah Raza; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Predicting Bazel build times using Machine Learning

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Join us as we share stories about the meaning of ""hermetic"" and how to achieve it in the context of builds. A meditation on the aesthetic aspects of build reproducibility.

Resources:
Hermeticity - Bazel main → https://goo.gle/3F1UpkN
Reproducible Builds → https://goo.gle/3D1JHu2

Speaker:
Benjamin Peterson

#BazelCon


product: Open Source - General; event: BazelCon 2021; fullname: Benjamin Peterson; re_ty: Publish;"
title: Reproducible builds with Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
This video starts with the gist of extending Bazel. Then we cover using the robust open core via BlazeModule subsets in new ways. We conclude with ideas and issues related to building powerful features and APIs.

Speaker: Jerry Marino
title: Beyond Bazel: Extending SkyFrame

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Radhika, Sven, and John share 2022 achievements, customer success stories and 2023 plans. Learn about Bazel roadmap, community contributions, and how you may participate in advancing the state of Bazel.

Speakers: John Field, Sven Tiffe, Radhika Advani
title: BazelCon 2022 State of the Union

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
In this 30 min Keynote, Jeff Cox, Sr Director of Engineering, who leads Google’s Core Developer Services organization, shares Bazel short term and long term goals for 2023, current and future OSS investments, and provide insights into Bazel value to Google and to 3rd party developers globally.

Speaker: Jeff Cox
title: BazelCon 2022 Keynote

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
This is a quick demo of what we have been doing with software supply chain audit in Bazel. See a demonstration of how we are doing it, what you can try today, and check out our roadmap for 2023.

Speaker: Tony Aiuto
title: Bazel software supply chain audit

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
VS Code is popular and a lot of developers at using it today. The Java support in VS Code works with Gradle and Maven. As we were migrating our monolith from Ant and Maven to Bazel, we needed a solution to support Java development. This talk introduces you to the Bazel VS Code Java extension and shows what's possible today and what limitations exist. We also talk about new feature coming in the next year.

Speaker: Gunnar Wagenknecht
title: Bazel and Java development in VS code

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
For each invocation, Bazel generates a profile that contains a broad source of performance information. However, interpreting this profile and acting on it requires significant expertise. Thus, Bazel profiles are often not utilized at all, or not to their full potential.

In this talk, we introduce the Bazel Invocation Analyzer: an open-source tool that automatically analyzes a Bazel profile and offers suggestions on how to enhance the invocation. We will demo how it can help Bazel users optimize their setup and improve their build and test performance.

Speaker: Sara Adams
title: Automatic suggestions for optimizing Bazel performance

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Google open-sourced Blaze, and some large companies have been able to replicate Google's success in using it. However, many more companies have tried, only to discover that Bazel doesn't have ""batteries included"".

Aspect's goal is to make a build system based on Bazel that's easier for companies to adopt and operate, both on developer's machines and on hosted services like CI. Come hear about our offering and our product roadmap.

Speaker: Alex Eagle
title: Aspect.build: An end-to-end Bazel experience developers want to use

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Bazel uses a combination of build-level and rule-level platform details to correctly configure actions and their prerequisite tools. Watch how action configuration works, understand recent changes to Bazel’s platforms, and learn how to modify your rules to ensure correct configuration, even in a multiplatform build environment.

Speakers: Susan Steinman, John Cater
title: Action configuration in Bazel

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
By default, Bazel requires that all targets agree on a single version for external dependencies. However, for Airbnb's JVM monorepo, one version is just not enough. In this talk, we share our approach to overcoming the single version requirement and unblocking our Bazel migration.

Speaker: Jack Dai
title: Accelerate Bazel migration with per-target version resolution

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Bazel's transitions are a very powerful concept that allows a rule and all its dependencies to be built with modified options such as compiler flags, build types or toolchain versions. While very useful, transitions are often regarded as complicated to use as they can only be directly attached to custom rules, not existing ones.

with_cfg is a new Starlark library that greatly reduces the amount of boilerplate required to create new rules out of old ones with an additional transition applied. Ever wanted a cc_asan_test that always runs a test with sanitizers or a java_21_library to use new language features in select parts of the codebase? After a quick introduction to transitions, this talk covers a number of such examples that all easily fit on a slide.

Speaker: Fabian Meumertzheim
title: with_cfg: Making transitions more accessible

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Validation actions are a Bazel feature designed to double-check build inputs and outputs for correctness, e.g., by applying static analysis. Bazel goes to great lengths to minimize overhead for validation actions and keeping them off the critical build path by letting validations run until the very end of a build, including in parallel with tests (i.e., after the ""normal"" build has finished). In this talk we go deeply into Bazel's building blocks to review how we pulled that off over the last 5 years: from output groups, to aspects, to Bazel's build event protocol. To illustrate their benefits, we'll show details on how validation actions help run Android Lint when building Google's Android apps. We'll also discuss some best practices and ideas for further improvement of validation actions.

Speakers: Kevin Bierhoff, Alex Humesky
title: Validation actions: correct builds off the critical path

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
It can sometimes be helpful to see a visual representation of a Bazel build graph. The query command supports this by letting you pipe output to Graphviz. However larger graphs quickly become a tangled mess of edges that are impossible to follow.

Skyscope is a new tool that aims to solve this problem. Instead of trying to render a large build graph in its entirety, only a few nodes are displayed at a time. You can click on various parts of the graph to display currently hidden nodes or hide visible ones. You can also search for nodes to display (e.g. by label or filename). This allows you to ""focus in"" on a particular area of interest, while keeping the complexity manageable.

The graphs are imported from Skyframe — Bazel's evaluation and incrementality model — so Skyscope should also be useful to people who want to understand more about how this part of Bazel works.

Speaker: Ben Radford
title: Visualizing Build Graphs with Skyscope

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Bazel is a powerful system for automating the building and testing of software. It's specifically designed to manage large codebases. However, it must be combined with the monorepo pattern to unlock Bazel's full potential. However, managing a monorepo with Git can be quite complex. Both submodules and subtrees have many limitations. The Mega from the Web3 Infrastructure Foundation offers an open source solution. Inspired by the Google Piper paper, Mega uses a distributed database to store massive amounts of code. It also achieves compatibility with the Git protocol. When used in conjunction with Bazel, Mega can truly unlock the full potential of these tools, providing a more efficient and scalable solution for managing large code bases.

Speaker: Quanyi Ma
title: Unlocking Bazel's Potential with Monorepo: A Key to Efficient Software Development

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Bazel relies on multiple layers of caching to make incremental builds fast, yet correct. The most important layer is the remote cache, which allows sharing build action results across machines. Getting a high cache hit ratio can be challenging in mixed environments, where developers, build machines, and target devices use different hardware – so-called ""cross-platform builds"". Bazel's ability to switch flags through configuration transitions, while powerful and flexible, also makes caching harder. In this talk, we'll survey ongoing efforts to make Bazel's use of the remote cache more efficient. In particular, we'll cover the following common use cases:

- Sharing build results between Linux build machines and Mac developer machines
- Sharing platform-independent build artifacts, such as Java libraries, between different target platforms.
- Preventing unnecessary rebuilds from configuration transitions.

Speakers: Greg Estren, Ara Nguyen, Tiago Quelhas, Fabian Meumertzheim
title: Towards Faster Cross-Platform Builds

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
With a 700+% YoY increase in supply chain attacks it becomes paramount for build systems to provide safety guarantees across the entire software development life cycle. One solution for this is to use the SLSA framework, to generate provenance for each build artifact, tying the artifact with the identity of the user building it and the (automated!) workflow used in the build process. This also enables testing that the builds are reproducible, increasing confidence that no backdoors/malware have been embedded during the build process. We will talk about a solution that would automatically add SLSA provenance to any project that builds using Bazel and GitHub Actions.

Speakers: Mihai Maruseac, Noah Elzner
title: Secure your Bazel artifacts using SLSA

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
A quick update on the status of rules_pkg, how Bazel is using it to produce SBOMs for itself, and plans for the next few quarters.

Speaker: Tony Aiuto
title: SBOMs via Bazel: Roadmap Update

author: The Linux Foundation
description: When building Bazel-integrated CI workflows, we initially tried to optimize performance by minimizing network bottlenecks in connecting to our remote cache and executors. Next, we realized the bottleneck was Bazel’s analysis phase. We started using Firecracker micro-VMs for our CI runs, which have a snapshotting mechanism that lets you serialize and save a running microVM. The snapshot can be later used to restore the microVM for subsequent CI runs. This lets us reuse the warm Bazel process and analysis cache from the earlier build, which can save several minutes for subsequent builds. We’ve reduced the median duration of our CI runs by nearly 8x, with most runs completing in just a few seconds. Now we’re continuing to improve our CI workflows by supporting remote snapshot sharing across machines. We’re able to store our snapshots remotely by using userfaultfd and network block devices to capture disk and memory reads/writes. This lets us maintain these performance benefits across mac
title: Reusing bazel’s analysis cache by cloning micro-VMs

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
The –remote_output_service is a community driven project with a fuse based companion program that allows your builds to not have their bytes and eat them too. Build without the bytes is a great feature of bazel that allows large builds to be completed without waiting eons to download the intermediate results. Sometimes you need a subset of the intermediate results and for that we have the remote output service.

In this talk we’ll go through the remote output service, its companion program bb-clientd, how it works and how it helps us get one step closer to finally ridding ourselves of all the bottlenecks.

Speaker: Benjamin Ingberg
title: Remote Output Service - How not to have your bytes and eat them too

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Bazel’s remote execution and caching capabilities are the bread and butter of how we keep builds at Stripe performant and efficient. Rather than using an open-source implementation, we maintain custom remote execution, caching and downloader implementations. We’ll discuss some of the more unique aspects of our system! Parts of this talk will be inspired by our blog post on the topic last year (https://goo.gle/47F6wlS).

Speaker: Sushain Cherivirala
title: Remote execution, the DIY edition

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Two years ago the RabbitMQ team at VMware was facing a challenge. Our CI pipeline could not keep up the rate of commits, and after we consolidated about 30 of our repositories into a monorepo, things only got worse. A single commit would take 2-3 hours to flow through the primary test suites, not including delays from flakes. We considered many options, but most of them felt like reinventing the wheel. Bazel seemed like a good solution, but a risky investment. Erlang and Elixir didn’t appear to be supported languages at the time, and the usability reputation for bazel was mixed. Nevertheless, 2-3 hours waiting for a commit leaves some time to experiment. This lead to the creation of `rules_erlang`, and with combination of Bazel and BuildBuddy, the time to green for a given commit dropped dramatically, something typically around 15 minutes. We would like to share some of the highs and lows of this journey with the Bazel community.

Speaker: Rin Kuryloski
title: RabbitMQ and the Story of rules_erlang

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
In recent years, Python’s popularity has soared, making it a go-to language for various software projects. Simultaneously, the Bazel build tool has gained traction as a powerful and scalable build system for large-scale projects.

This lighting talk touches on the present and future states of Python integration with Bazel, exploring the challenges developers face and the solutions that lie ahead. We’ll discuss the strengths and limitations of existing methods for incorporating Python into Bazel workflows, and identify areas for improvement.

Central to our discussion will be Aspect Build’s rules_py, an alternative approach to Python integration with Bazel. We will showcase how Aspect’s rules_py differs from rules_python, highlighting the benefits it offers to developers.

Speaker: Matt Mackay
title: Python and Bazel: Aspect’s rules_py

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
A tale of how we modernized a 20 year old codebase and how Bazel helped driving it.

Speaker: Manuel Naranjo
title: Planting Bazel in barren soil: A Perl Story

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
Deep dive into definitions, tips, tricks and footguns when it come to Bazel's toolchains, platforms and build configuration for a multi-platform RBE setup. 

Speaker: Son Luong Ngoc
title: Multi-platforms Build with Remote Build Execution

author: The Linux Foundation
description:
NeoX is a multiple-platform game engine developed by Netease. In 2022, we successfully moved to bazel to build NeoX for three target platforms: Windows, iOS, and Android—all with IDE integration(Visual Studio, Xcode, and Android Studio) and remote execution. To support remote execution on the Windows and iOS platform, we also developed and open-sourced a remote worker that supports Windows and macOS host platforms. We will share how we gradually moved from a cmake-based solution to bazel, and how we set up remote execution for the Windows and the iOS platform. We will also share the tools we used to integrate bazel with IDEs. At last, we will talk about what new features we expect from bazel in the future to better support cross-platform projects like the game engines.

Speaker: Kai Zhang
title: Migrating a multiple-platform game engine to Bazel
